Award.AwardTitle: Group travel to the Past Antarctic Ice Sheet Dynamics (PAIS) 2017 Conference, Trieste, Italy
Award.AbstractNarration:
The first international Past Antarctic Ice Sheet dynamics (PAIS) conference will be held September 10-15, 2017 in Trieste, Italy. The PAIS research program was recently formed by the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR), and grew out of the 2009 Antarctic Climate Evolution symposium. The goal of the workshop is to address key questions about the sensitivity of the Antarctic Ice Sheet to climate change and its contribution to past and future sea level change. The funds will be used to support travel costs for approximately 7-10 U.S. scientists, including early career researchers and graduate students, enabling them to present their scientific findings and benefit from the scholarly exchange of ideas. Travel support requests will be reviewed by an ad hoc review committee made up of standing PAIS advisory committee members. The committee members include both international and U.S. scientists. The review committee will follow NSF guidelines on conflicts of interest in their review process.

The future response of the Antarctic Ice Sheet to a warming atmosphere and ocean will have a fundamental impact on global and local sea level rise, coastal cities, communities, and strategic infrastructure. The PAIS conference will facilitate the integration of the latest developments in numerical climate-ocean-ice-Earth modeling with the latest information on recent and past changes in the ice sheet, to better inform projections of the region's physical and ecological future. This grant will allow US researchers, early career scientists, and graduate students to attend the 2017 PAIS Conference and associated workshops. Symposium presentations and publications will provide an important record of research activities in Antarctic Earth Sciences and Glaciology. The key outcomes of the conference and ancillary workshops will set the stage for future international and interdisciplinary collaborations and research proposals- particularly those linking observations and numerical modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided travel and logistical support for the attendance of American graduate students, post doctoral researchers, and senior researchers at a major international science symposium focusing on past, present, and future changes in the Antarctic Ice Sheet- and the associated implications for future sea level rise. The September, 2017 conference, held in Trieste Italy, was sponsored and supported by the Scientific Committee for Antarctic Research, under the auspices of the International Science Council, which works directly with the United Nations. The five-day science conference was attended by more than 200 Antarctic science experts from 17 countries. The conference specifically encouraged the engagement of graduate students and early career scientists (30% of participants). The meeting encompassed 62 oral presentations and 130 posters. American participants supported by this NSF award included four invited speakers (two female and two male), five American Ph.D. students (four female and one male), and one American post doctoral fellow (female). Travel support was provided according to need, and a competitive application process. The female post doc supported by this award is now an Assistant Professor at a major American University. She has recently been recruited into leadership roles in Antarctic research programs and is now developing her own independent science proposals.

In addition to daily oral and poster sessions, the conference included a number of outreach and side events (workshops and films) involving local schools (about 500 students and their teachers), the public, and the media. One major outcome of the conference and associated workshops was a comprehensive evaluation of the current state of Antarctic ice sheet and sea-level science. U.S. participation and input were important, because the conference outcomes are being used to help guide future research priorities within the framework of the Scientific Committee for Antarctic Research, and other major international data-acquisition programs including the European Project for Ice Coring in Antarctica, and the International Ocean Discovery Program, the latter of which is largely supported by the U.S.
